Galois group of a Field Extension
The Galois group $\\operatorname{Gal}(L / K)$ of an extension $L / K$ is the group of all field automorphisms of $L$ that fix every element of $K$.
Galois Group of a Finite Field Extension

The Galois group, or automorphism group, $\\[\operatorname{Aut}_{\mathbb{F}_q}(\mathbb{F}_{q'})\]$ of a finite field extension $\\[\mathbb{F}_{q'} / \mathbb{F}_q\]$ is the group of field automorphisms of $\\[\mathbb{F}_{q'}\]$ that fix $\\[\mathbb{F}_q\]$. It is cyclic of order $n$, where $n$ is the degree of the extension.

Does the concept of a/an Galois group of a Field Extension need to be defined for a definition of a/an Galois Group of a Finite Field Extension to make sense? (True if the first concept is needed and False if is not.)

Explanation:
The concept of the Galois group of a field extension is a general definition that applies to any field extension, where the group consists of all automorphisms of the larger field that fix every element of the smaller field. This definition is crucial as it sets the foundational understanding of what a Galois group is in the context of field theory.

The concept of the Galois group of a finite field extension is a specific instance of the general concept, applied to finite fields. It specifies that the group is cyclic and its order is the degree of the extension, which is additional information specific to finite fields. However, the core idea of automorphisms fixing the smaller field remains the same.

Therefore, understanding the general concept of the Galois group of a field extension is necessary to grasp the specific case of finite field extensions. Without the general concept, the specific definition lacks the foundational context needed to fully understand its structure and properties.
